column4: hi. I am trying to delete lots of files with + signs in their file names. I tried this: rm *+*, but rm complains: rm: invalid option -- '+' Try `rm ./'-+ (705)'' to remove the file. what can I do about that?
that did not help. I think the problem is that the wildcard is being extended by the shell and the resulting file names are not quoted.
if the filename is test+name.file rm test\+name.file should work
repeating the same question every 2 minutes will not help
please ask the question, wait a while to se if anyone knows, if they don't wait a while and ask later
you obviously didn't read the question. but I have an answer, don't worry.
sorry, that was for paddy
apologies
typo
that's a very bad idea
why?
do you really need 1 4TB file system ?
it's convenient. why is it a bad idea? because of disk failure rates and the increased risk?

1.) it's external storage so on a slow bus 2.) you'd have to use fakeraid (terrible idea) or software raid, but with external storage poor performance c.) you'd have to use gpt partition tables d.) slightest corruption and you use all your data
hm ok. so, I should rather treat them as two separate drives, so that if one fails, the other one isn't hit?
correct, and it's not even a failure, it's file system corruption that would cause you the main issue
good point, you have convinced me. but not having to use gpt isn't really a good argument since we will have to use gpt some day any way. :p
do you know how to manage the gpt partitions in Linux ?
yes, I read about it, never tested it though. and even if I did not know, I still have to learn it since it's only a matter of time till >2TB drives become standard usage.
it is not a matter of time until 2TB become standard.
you sound like Bill Gates arguing that 64K is enough for everybody.
